There are 3 different configurations I found that have advantages and disadvantages. 1. Handheld mode, 1x resolution This is the most stable setting, but is only 720p and has a 7-chunk render distance. Perfect 60fps, extremely rarely freezes (but there is auto-save every minute or so, so don't worry). 2. Docked mode, 0.75x resolution. Less stable, but gives a 810p resolution (not a typo, it is actually 810p) and has a 10-chunk render distance. Gameplay is almost always at 60fps, with rare dips to 55 or so. Freezes are infrequent, but not impossible. 3. Docked mode, 1x resolution. The least stable, but most impressive graphics. 1080p and 10-chunk render distance. Performance is also almost always at 60fps, but freezes are pretty common, maybe every 10-15 minutes or so. Also, make sure you use Turnip Driver 9v2 AND cubeb audio. Audio is totally messed up without cubeb.

rows.game: Legend Of Zelda: Breath Of The Wild
rows.notes:
As of September 25th 2025 Citron is still the current best way to play BOTW! Follow my instructions to get a perfect 35-40 FPS in the open world and 60FPS in shrines

- Install game update 1.6.0
- Set resolution to 0.75x in graphic settings
- set force maximum clocks to on
- set use async shaders to on
- Install the pre-configured ultracam files from this link: https://drive.google.com/file/d/11LNdPKfhLGUcuLTtknKuWq4BZBDJ3i5M/view?usp=sharing
- Extract the file above and place the "Ultracam" folder in the following directory on your device Internal shared storage\Android\data\org.citron.citron_emu\files\load\01007EF00011E000
- On your retroid go to BOTW in Citron and click on "Add-ons" and make sure that UltraCam is toggled on. 

Tip: To fix the white water reflection bug, go near some water in the game (pond, river ect) and then save your game, Exit the game completely by closing Citron, Go back into Citron and clear the shader cache for BOTW and then load back in from the save you did earlier from near the water, you will load near the water and this time the water reflections will work properly. You will need to repeat this if you swap to any other driver in the future so just stay on Mr Purple T19.

rows.game: Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword HD
rows.notes:
Was able to play through the entirety of the game, completed sidequests and collected all gratitude crystals. 100% is possible, but expect to run into some issues here and there. I experienced many crashes, and I found an odd issue when using pretty much any turnip driver. Turnips make the game look pretty much 100% accurate to the switch itself, and minimal graphical issues, but it absolutely hated rendering the maps. You need to consult the map very often in game, and when you open the map menu, sometimes it would simply display and extremely distorted, broken, messed up image of the map as of the vertex mathematics used to draw the map was absolutely broken. Other times, it would sieze up the entire retroid pocket flip 2, right on the first frame of it trying to generate the map, and would cause a hard device crash. I highly avoid using any turnips with this game.

Surprisingly enough, after much hassle I found that the stock Qualcomm driver that you can select in eden would work significantly better. I ended up playing through 99% of the game with the basic driver. It did cause some graphical oddities in some areas of the game. For instance, when grass was cut it wouldn't animate it properly, or parts of peoples faces would look transparent in certain cutscenes. It also seems to make the sky in the games opening menu darker and blurrier for some reason, as well as one of the endgame cutzcenes with levias. I'd say it's worth it to deal with a little graphical glitch in some minimal spots of the game, rather than risking crashing my whole device with a perfect looking game with a turnip driver. 

But then even though I found that while the stock driver is, while a bit buggy, the most stable, it actually would still crash in the semi-final boss fight with ghirahim. It crashed on twice right as he starts to pull out his sword, so for that one boss fight, I switched back to a turnip driver. It worked, I beat him, and then closed yet again to switch back to stock driver.

rows.game: Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword HD
rows.notes:
Was able to play through the entirety of the game, completed sidequests and collected all gratitude crystals. 100% is possible, but expect to run into some issues here and there. I experienced many crashes, and I found an odd issue when using pretty much any turnip driver. Turnips make the game look pretty much 100% accurate to the switch itself, and minimal graphical issues, but it absolutely hated rendering the maps. You need to consult the map very often in game, and when you open the map menu, sometimes it would simply display and extremely distorted, broken, messed up image of the map as of the vertex mathematics used to draw the map was absolutely broken. Other times, it would sieze up the entire retroid pocket flip 2, right on the first frame of it trying to generate the map, and would cause a hard device crash. I highly avoid using any turnips with this game.

Surprisingly enough, after much hassle I found that the stock Qualcomm driver that you can select in eden would work significantly better. I ended up playing through 99% of the game with the basic driver. It did cause some graphical oddities in some areas of the game. For instance, when grass was cut it wouldn't animate it properly, or parts of peoples faces would look transparent in certain cutscenes. It also seems to make the sky in the games opening menu darker and blurrier for some reason, as well as one of the endgame cutzcenes with levias. I'd say it's worth it to deal with a little graphical glitch in some minimal spots of the game, rather than risking crashing my whole device with a perfect looking game with a turnip driver. 

But then even though I found that while the stock driver is, while a bit buggy, the most stable, it actually would still crash in the semi-final boss fight with ghirahim. It crashed on twice right as he starts to pull out his sword, so for that one boss fight, I switched back to a turnip driver. It worked, I beat him, and then closed yet again to switch back to stock driver. 

It is definitely some hassle. But it can work, and I got to replay a really great zelda game from start to credits.
